awd_titl_txt: GOALI: In-Situ Plasma Cleaning of Optics: Building a Fundamental Understanding of the Etch Process in a Complex Plasma Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Extreme-Ultraviolet (EUV) light holds strong promise as a light source for producing tomorrow's complex and compact integrated circuits. Unfortunately, practical economic use is currently precluded by low cost-efficiency for high volume manufacturing. The EUV source uses tin (Sn) droplets to produce the 13.5nm light, which is collected and transmitted into a scanner by collector optics. Sn deposits on the collector surface and degrades the EUV reflectivity. Cleaning Sn using hydrogen radicals is a potential solution. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports the Applied Research Institute at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign to perform basic research in collaboration with its industrial partners to advance the fundamental understanding of the underlying physics and chemistry of Sn etch process using hydrogen radicals. This research will prove to be a milestone in the success of the next generation chip manufacturing process, which will enable a cost effective implementation of the technology to print smarter chips and eventually improve the speed and performance of electronic devices. An overarching goal of this research is the integration of research findings into academic courses, student involvement with industry, and attracting young scientists into the vast field of plasma engineering.

This project is a hypothesis-driven, theoretical and experimental study of Sn cleaning from optics in a complex plasma environment. It focuses on fundamental understanding of reactive particle formation in hydrogen plasma, its arrival and interaction with surfaces, adsorption mechanisms, bond formation with the surface to be etched, and then finally the formation and desorption of product molecules under the EUV source operating environment. The team will perform a thorough computational analysis of the dependencies of hydrogen plasma conditions and etch rate. Etching experiments will be run to validate the etch rates predicted by the models. Collaborative industrial partners will help by providing necessary equipment, metrologies and the plasma source to advance this research. The research will answer  fundamental questions in the field of plasma material interaction, surface science, plasma processing and etching.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The next level of an advanced electronics requires more efficient and less time-consuming production technology. Among other options of how to achieve a cost effective production technology is to implement an Extreme UltraViolet (EUV) lithography. At their current state the EUV light sources can pattern wafers successfully but not quick or reliably enough for high volume manufacturing (HVM) adoption. The key feature to be improved is source availability, which means that an EUV source should work 24/7 for the whole year and without any downtime for maintenance.

The reason for a source downtime is a necessity for mirrors cleaning. And cleaning is a huge undertaking because the current state of the art technology utilizes highly ionized tin to produce EUV light. To achieve EUV emission from tin atoms a small droplet of tin should be blasted with high energy laser and to get intensity of the light, which would be good enough for lithography process, the tin droplets should be blasted tens of thousands of times per second. This results in several kilograms of evaporated tin deposited on walls and mirrors inside an EUV chamber source. Before  the source should have been switched off for a long time relatively often to replace mirrors and clean chamber walls.

And cleaning should be super-efficient because EUV lithography uses 13.5 nm light from a laser-produced tin (Sn) plasma. This wavelength is readily absorbed and must be transmitted using a series of multilayer mirrors (MLMs). The mirror reflectivity is critical in determining EUV power at the wafer. Each mirror has a reflectivity from 60-70%. In a chain of ten mirrors the final power is drastically reduced. The tin deposition contaminates the MLM eventually through direct deposition of nanometer layers or possible macroscopic secondary contamination from the source walls. This causes drastic reduction in mirror reflectivity and end-of-the-line power. The cleaning or replacing of the collector mirror is a major contributor to source downtime/availability.

In order to prolong the lifetime of the collector and keep the source walls free from Sn, an in-situ cleaning method is needed. And this method was developed at CPMI at UIUC in collaboration with Starfire Industries LLC. The method perfectly fits into a production chamber because the EUV source is run with a background of hydrogen gas. And hydrogen radicals chemically etch tin by forming a gaseous tin hydride. Previously it has been shown that a hydrogen plasma can be used to clean the collector and regain near-original reflectivity. This method requires no tool downtime as it operates using the background hydrogen already present in the system. Given the demonstration of collector cleaning, the new goal of this project is to develop an in-situ, large scale method to remove Sn across the entire collector.

An investigation into the fundamentals of this Sn etch by hydrogen has already been conducted. It was found that the highest etch rates are achieved when the plasma is in the reactive ion etch regime. Hydrogen ions impact the surface Sn, breaking bonds and helping to form SnH4. This project was seeking optimization of the chamber and the plasma parameters to achieve the highest Sn removal rate possible. Etch rates and radical densities have been measured over different pressures in order to determine the best operation pressure.

In addition to finding the optimal pressure, a new plasma source was used to form the hydrogen plasma. A Surface Wave Plasma (SWP) has been proposed for its high radical and ion densities while having low electron temperatures and ion energies. Lower ion energies reduce the probability of hydrogen ions implanting in the Multilayer Mirror MLM. The combination of ion densities on the order of 1011-12 cm-3 and radical densities on the order of 1014 cm-3 are expected to yield higher etch rates of Sn that has been seen previously.

The SWP used was designed to deliver power at the source radius (2.5 inches) and was called MSWP. For collector etching, plasma should etch the whole surface. Thus need to test an SWP antenna that generates plasma larger than the source radius. Etching was done using this Starfire source in order to determine if such a plasma could be generated and could etch. This was succesfully achieved.

The last step was to incorporate the SWP into a fundamental component of the commercial Cymer system. Using an existing piece of the Cymer system as a basis, a SWP was designed to be unobtrusive and generate etching plasma that can operate during EUV light production. The proof-of-concept system was tested in a Cymer system and results are shown on figure 1. The radius of the etching zone and the etch rate made the SWP system the win candidate for industrial process and pre-manufacturing trials are planned with Cymer company.


Last Modified: 11/16/2017
Modified by: David N Ruzic

    David N Ruzic
    Collector etch efficiency, test results
